title: Garth Williams
text:
Garth Montgomery Williams (April 16, 1912 – May 8, 1996) was an American artist who came to prominence in the American <a href="Post-war">postwar era</a> as an <a href="illustrator">illustrator</a> of children's books. Many of the books he illustrated have become classics of American <a href="children%27s%20literature">children's literature</a>.
His friendly, fuzzy baby animals populated a dozen <a href="Little%20Golden%20Books">Little Golden Books</a>.
<a href="Mel%20Gussow">Mel Gussow</a> in "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" wrote, "He believed that books 'given, or read, to children can have a profound influence!' For that reason, he said, he used his illustrations to try to 'awaken something of importance  ... humor, responsibility, respect for others, interest in the world at large!'"
Early life.
Born in New York City in 1912, Williams's father was a <a href="cartoonist">cartoonist</a> for "<a href="Punch%20%28magazine%29">Punch</a>" and his mother was a <a href="landscape%20painter">landscape painter</a>. He described them by saying, "Everybody in my home was always either painting or drawing." He grew up on farms in <a href="New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a> and <a href="Canada">Canada</a> until the family relocated to the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> in 1922, where his parents were from.
Williams studied <a href="architecture">architecture</a> there, and worked for a time as an architect's assistant. When the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a> came, he made up his mind to be an artist instead of an architect. He began his studies at <a href="Westminster%20School%20of%20Art">Westminster School of Art</a> in 1929 and, in 1931, was awarded a four-year scholarship to the <a href="Royal%20College%20of%20Art">Royal College of Art</a> where he created a sculpture that was awarded the <a href="British%20Prix%20de%20Rome">British Prix de Rome</a>. He continued his education at the <a href="British%20School%20at%20Rome">British School at Rome</a> in Germany and Italy, until the outbreak of World War II in Europe.
In London, he volunteered with the <a href="British%20Red%20Cross">British Red Cross</a> Civilian Defense ambulances, and helped collect the dead and injured from the streets. After a bomb blast vaporized a friend who had been walking next to him, he sent his wife and daughter to Canada, and reunited with them in New York in 1942.
Career.
In the United States, Williams worked making <a href="lens%20%28optics%29">lens</a>es at a war plant, applied for work as a <a href="camouflage">camouflage</a> artist, contributed war-effort posters to the British-American Art Center in New York, and brought his portfolio around to the major publishing houses. He drew for "<a href="The%20New%20Yorker">The New Yorker</a>" for a mutually unfulfilling period of time. Then, in 1945, he received his first commission as an illustrator, from editor <a href="Ursula%20Nordstrom">Ursula Nordstrom</a> of <a href="HarperCollins">Harper</a>'s Department of Books for Boys and Girls. The story is that Nordstrom "told him she was expecting a manuscript that he might illustrate. By coincidence, when the manuscript arrived the author had pinned a note to it: 'Try Garth Williams'. The author was <a href="E.%20B.%20White">E. B. White</a>; the book was "Stuart Little"." The Whites had wanted <a href="Robert%20Lawson%20%28author%29">Robert Lawson</a> to work on the project, but had burned through eight illustrators. The book became a success with adults as well as children. Williams later said that seeing grownups on buses and trains reading "Stuart Little" persuaded him to continue as a freelance illustrator.
Soon after, he began collaborating with <a href="Margaret%20Wise%20Brown">Margaret Wise Brown</a> with "<a href="The%20Little%20Fur%20Family">The Little Fur Family</a>", Harper's answer to <a href="Simon%20%26amp%3B%20Schuster">Simon & Schuster's</a> "<a href="Pat%20the%20Bunny">Pat the Bunny</a>". Nordstrom knew that the book would be a success when a mother wrote to tell her that her little boy had held open his copy at the dinner table, and tried to feed it his supper. In all, Williams illustrated eleven of Brown's books.
In 1951 he illustrated "Charlotte's Web" (1952); his eldest child Fiona, who was a toddler when the family escaped <a href="the%20Blitz">the Blitz</a>, was his model for Fern Arable.
In the latter part of his life, Williams lived primarily in Marfil, a small town west of <a href="Guanajuato%2C%20Guanajuato">Guanajuato, Mexico</a>. He was part of a colony of <a href="expatriates">expatriates</a> who built or rebuilt homes in the ruins of the silver mines of <a href="colonial%20Mexico">colonial Mexico</a>. At 81, he estimated that he had illustrated 97 books.
At 84 Williams died at his home in Marfil, and was buried in <a href="Aspen%2C%20Colorado">Aspen, Colorado</a>. He had been married four times and had five daughters: Fiona and Bettina from his first marriage; Jessica and Estyn from his second; Dilys from his fourth; and a son, Dylan, from his third marriage.
"Little House" illustrations (1953).
Williams received the commission to illustrate the new "Little House" edition in about 1947. To know the worlds of Laura's childhood, Williams, who had never been west of the <a href="Hudson%20River">Hudson River</a>, traveled the <a href="American%20Midwest">American Midwest</a> to the places <a href="Laura%20Ingalls%20Wilder">the Ingalls family</a> had lived 70 years before, photographing and sketching landscapes, trees, birds and wildlife, buildings and towns. "The trip culminated in a search along the riverbank along <a href="Plum%20Creek%20%28Redwood%20County%2C%20Minnesota%29">Plum Creek</a> where the family had once built their dugout home.
I did not expect to find the house, but I felt certain that it would have left an indentation in the bank. A light rain did not help my search, and I was about to give up when ahead of me I saw exactly what I was looking for, a hollow in the east bank of Plum Creek. I felt very well rewarded, for the scene fitted Mrs Wilder's description perfectly... [He] wanted to  ... be able to see the house on Plum Creek  ... as Laura would have done, as a happy, flower bedecked refuge from the elements, with the music of the nearby stream. Which is how he drew it.Ursula Nordstrom's initial plan was for Williams to produce eight oil paintings for each book, sixty-four in all. This proved to be not cost-efficient. Williams illustrated the "Little House" books with a simple pencil, charcoal, and ink. Much of his work was accomplished in Italy.
Williams later illustrated the first edition of "<a href="The%20First%20Four%20Years%20%28novel%29">The First Four Years</a>" (1971), which is commonly considered the last of nine books in the Little House series.
"The Rabbits' Wedding" controversy (1958).
In 1958, Garth Williams wrote and illustrated a picture book that caused a small uproar: "<a href="The%20Rabbits%27%20Wedding">The Rabbits' Wedding</a>". Aimed at children aged 3 to 7, it depicted animals in a moonlit forest attending the wedding of a white rabbit to a black rabbit. In 1959, <a href="Alabama">Alabama</a> Senator E. O. Eddins and Alabama State Library Agency director <a href="Emily%20Wheelock%20Reed">Emily Wheelock Reed</a> took the lead in a controversy over the book. Senator Eddins, with the support of the <a href="Citizens%27%20Councils">White Citizens' Council</a> and other segregationists, demanded that it be removed from all Alabama libraries because of its perceived themes of <a href="racial%20integration">racial integration</a> and <a href="interracial%20marriage">interracial marriage</a>. Reed reviewed the book and, finding no objectionable content, determined it was her ethical duty to defend the book against an outright ban. A battle ensued between Reed and her supporters, and the segregationist faction in the legislature. In the end, the book was not banned outright, but rather placed on special reserve shelves in the state library agency-run facilities. Libraries that had purchased their own copies were not required to make this change.
About the controversy, Williams stated, "I was completely unaware that animals with white fur, such as white polar bears and white dogs and white rabbits, were considered blood relations of white beings. I was only aware that a white horse next to a black horse looks very picturesque." Williams said his story was not written for adults, who "will not understand it, because it is only about a soft furry love and has no hidden message of hate".
Techniques.
In a 1980 interview, Williams described his approach to illustrating stories by other writers. His initial reading of the material usually would suggest thirty or forty potential pictures. "To compose the pictures is very hard  ... I look for all the action in the story; then I arrange forms and color. I always try to imagine what the author is seeing. Of course, I have to narrow down my ideas to the number of drawings I'm allowed, which might be as few as ten per book. I make a list of illustrations. When I see a picture, I write down the idea and a page number while I read the manuscript."
Williams drew few straight lines. He used charcoal and graphite pencils, from fine to very soft, to illustrate the <a href="Little%20House%20books">Little House books</a>. The "youngest" book in the series, "Little House in the Big Woods," is nearly lamplit in its coziness, almost an echo of the small-animal sensibilities of The Fur Family or his deeply colored <a href="Little%20Golden%20Books">Little Golden Books</a>. He used pen and ink for "<a href="The%20Cricket%20in%20Times%20Square">The Cricket in Times Square</a>", the "Rescuers" books, "Charlotte's Web", and "Stuart Little". "The Giant Golden Book of Elves and Fairies", a 1951 anthology, is noteworthy for Williams' extensive use of colored pencil. In the Golden Books and Little Golden Books, he favored oil pastels, ink washes, and watercolor. "The Rabbits' Wedding" (1958), which employed a limited palette of only a few delicate colors, contained some of the best-reproduced examples of his ability to convey hair, hide, grass, and fur textures.
